title: Colorectal Cancer Early Screening: Why It Matters and The Complete Handbook to Get Tested
section: Colorectal cancer—affecting the colon or rectum—is one of the most common cancers worldwide, but it’s also highly preventable and treatable when detected early. Early screening can identify precancerous polyps (abnormal growths) before they turn into cancer, or catch cancer in its earliest stages when treatment is most effective. This article explains who needs screening, available tests, and why staying proactive is critical.
content:
Why Early Screening for Colorectal Cancer Is Important

• Highly preventable: Most colorectal cancers start as polyps, which can take 10–15 years to develop into cancer. Screening finds these polyps, allowing doctors to remove them before they become cancerous.

• Better treatment outcomes: When caught early (localized to the colon or rectum), the 5-year survival rate is over 90%. For advanced stages, the rate drops significantly.

• Asymptomatic in early stages: Colorectal cancer often has no symptoms in its early phases. By the time symptoms (e.g., blood in stool, weight loss, abdominal pain) appear, the cancer may have spread. Screening is the only way to detect it early.

Who Should Get Screened?

• Average risk individuals: Start screening at age 45. This includes people with no family history of colorectal cancer, no personal history of polyps, and no inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

• Higher risk individuals: Start screening earlier (age 40 or 10 years before the youngest affected family member’s diagnosis) if:

?nbsp;A first-degree relative (parent, sibling, child) had colorectal cancer or polyps.

?nbsp;You have a personal history of polyps or colorectal cancer.

?nbsp;You have IBD (e.g., ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease) or a genetic syndrome (e.g., Lynch syndrome).

Screening should continue until at least age 75; adults 76–85 should discuss with their doctor whether to continue, based on overall health and life expectancy.

Types of Colorectal Cancer Screening Tests

Several tests are available, varying in frequency, invasiveness, and accuracy. Discuss with your doctor to choose the best option for you.

1. Colonoscopy

• How it works: A doctor uses a flexible tube with a camera to examine the entire colon and rectum. Precancerous polyps can be removed during the procedure, and tissue samples (biopsies) can be taken if abnormalities are found.

• Frequency: Every 10 years (or more often if polyps are found).

• Pros: Most accurate test; can prevent cancer by removing polyps.

• Cons: Requires bowel preparation (clear liquid diet and laxatives the day before) to empty the colon. Mild discomfort or cramping during the procedure, which is often done with sedation. Rare risks: Bleeding (from polyp removal) or perforation (tear in the colon, less than 1 in 1,000 cases).

2. Fecal Immunochemical Test (FIT)

• How it works: A non-invasive test that checks for hidden blood in stool (a sign of polyps or cancer). At-home kits use a small stool sample, which is mailed to a lab.

• Frequency: Annually.

• Pros: No bowel prep or sedation; easy to do at home.

• Cons: Less accurate than colonoscopy. A positive result requires follow-up with a colonoscopy to confirm findings. May miss some polyps or cancers that don’t bleed.

3. Fecal Occult Blood Test (gFOBT)

• How it works: Similar to FIT but uses a chemical reaction to detect blood in stool. Also done at home with stool samples.

• Frequency: Annually.

• Pros: Low cost, non-invasive.

• Cons: Less accurate than FIT or colonoscopy. Diet restrictions (avoid red meat, vitamin C) before the test to prevent false positives. Positive results require a colonoscopy.

4. Stool DNA Test (e.g., Cologuard)

• How it works: Detects both hidden blood and abnormal DNA in stool (shed by polyps or cancer cells). At-home test with a stool sample.

• Frequency: Every 3 years.

• Pros: No bowel prep; combines blood and DNA detection for higher accuracy than FIT alone.

• Cons: More expensive than FIT. Higher false-positive rate than colonoscopy, meaning more unnecessary follow-up colonoscopies.

5. Flexible Sigmoidoscopy

• How it works: A shorter tube examines the lower third of the colon and rectum for polyps or cancer. Polyps in this area can be removed during the test.

• Frequency: Every 5 years (often combined with annual FIT for better accuracy).

• Pros: No sedation needed; less bowel prep than colonoscopy.

• Cons: Only examines part of the colon, so may miss polyps in the upper colon.

How to Prepare for Screening

• Colonoscopy: Follow your doctor’s instructions for bowel prep (usually a clear liquid diet 1–2 days before, plus laxatives or enemas to empty the colon). Arrange for a ride home, as sedation impairs driving.

• At-home tests (FIT, gFOBT, stool DNA): Read instructions carefully. Collect samples as directed, avoid contamination, and mail promptly. For FIT/gFOBT, avoid certain foods or medications if instructed.

Common Myths About Colorectal Cancer Screening

• Myth: “I’m too young to need screening.”

Fact: While rare, colorectal cancer can occur in people under 45. Cases in younger adults are rising, so guidelines now start at 45.

• Myth: “The prep for colonoscopy is too unpleasant.”

Fact: Prep has improved—many kits use smaller volumes of liquid or flavored solutions. The temporary discomfort is far better than treating advanced cancer.

• Myth: “If I have no symptoms, I don’t need screening.”

Fact: Early cancer often has no symptoms. Screening is the only way to detect it early.

• Myth: “Screening is only for people with a family history.”

Fact: Most people with colorectal cancer have no family history. Everyone at average risk needs screening.

FAQs About Colorectal Cancer Screening

• Is colorectal cancer screening covered by insurance? Most insurance plans cover recommended screening tests (e.g., colonoscopy every 10 years, annual FIT) with no out-of-pocket costs, as required by health guidelines.

• What if a polyp is found during screening? Most polyps are non-cancerous. Doctors remove them during colonoscopy, and larger or suspicious polyps may be tested for cancer. Follow-up screening is scheduled more frequently (e.g., every 3–5 years).

• Can I skip screening if I eat a healthy diet? No—while a diet high in fiber and low in red/processed meat reduces risk, it doesn’t eliminate it. Screening is still necessary.

• How long does a colonoscopy take? The procedure itself takes 30–60 minutes, plus time for sedation recovery (1–2 hours).

Colorectal cancer is a leading cause of cancer deaths, but early screening can drastically reduce this risk. By understanding your risk, choosing a screening test that works for you, and sticking to the recommended schedule, you take a powerful step toward prevention and early detection. Talk to your doctor today about which test is right for you—your future self will thank you.
